texts.definition: The goal of moving a certain game element to another specified game element or place within the game space.
markups: <style="Definition">The goal of moving a certain game element to another specified game element or place within the game space.</style>

Many games make goals of having specific game elements in specific places of the game world. <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals are such goals but where a focus is placed on the moving of specific rather than general game elements.
<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Football">Football</link></style> can be described as the task of delivering the ball into the other team's goal.

Capture the flag variants of first-person shooters such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unreal%20Tournament%20series">Unreal Tournament series</link></style> have the goal of gaining access of the other team's flag and carrying it to one's own capture point.

The "Fairgrounds" level in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%202">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> has an optional goal consisting of transporting a garden gnome to a rescue vehicle.

Many games, e.g., the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>, that have vast game spaces and non-players character make use of <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> quests. A side effect of performing these is that it makes players see more parts of the game worlds than they might otherwise do.

<style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> requires something to deliver somewhere and that the player has means of moving that. The latter part of this typically implies that players have to engage in some form of <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> in general suit as the things to be delivered. <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> can be used for <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals that are intended to be more significant since these add a narration importance. <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> are an option if their movement is indirectly controlled by a player (i.e., a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Control">Indirect Control</link></style>) - a natural option is that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">Non-Player Characters</link></style> follows players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> (but <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style> can work also). Players may automatically gain the thing to <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> as the set-up of the goal, but the goal can be made more challenging by first requiring a <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goal to be fulfilled (e.g., through <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>).

The somewhere that the delivery should go can be anywhere,but design goals related to <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> can require motivations for why the thing should be delivered to the place. <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> that want to have the thing is a standard option. <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> is another option when the things delivered are needed to use or activate the <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, e.g., delivering a certain magic gem to a circle of runes to activate them.

The place chosen as a delivery point for <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals can be seen (or made into) a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Check%20Point">Check Points</link></style>. Additionally, for games with <style="Link"><link="pervasive-gameplay">Pervasive Gameplay</link></style> <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals may need <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style> goals to be part of the game state.

<style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> differs from <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style> in that the focus is on specific game elements that needs to be moved to specific places. <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style> in contrast focus upon having game elements together, and there might be many different game elements that can take a place in the collection.

The difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals can be modified by requiring <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> subgoals to be dealt with. An archetypical example is bandit or pirates that try to steal what is to be delivered as it is being moved.

<style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> can be used to make is possible to remove the thing to be delivered from a player's control, and this in turn creates a <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goal for players.

Having <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> (besides the delivery point) allows games to show players their progress in <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals and possibly more advanced starting positions after failed attempts to <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals can quite easily be constructed to drive narration in that succeeding with such a goal implies clear actions having been performed by the player, and that the story arcs for various <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can be updated depending on this. While <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can be built from the pattern, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> can also provide information and motivation for the pattern.

By their structure, <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals provide games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Goal%20Points">Goal Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals, and a basis for <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>. Depending on how <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> is made possible of what is to be delivered, <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> may be a consequence of <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style>. <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals where active opposition exists (typically in the form of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals), give players <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> goals. Those <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals that depend on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Control">Indirect Control</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> can create <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals - moving a group of animals from one spot to another is an example of such a <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goal.

The combination of <style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> and <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guide%20and%20Protect">Guide and Protect</link></style> goals when what is to be delivered has some semblance of agency (e.g., by being <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Deliver</style> goals making use of <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style> typically have <style="Link"><link="player-location-proximity">Player-Location Proximity</link></style> as a consequence (unless the artifact is moved by a player without the player moving).
